6.0	Updates (68.190)

6.1	Policy 
HUNTSMAN will review and update its RMP as specified below and/ or submit it in a method and format as required by EPA regulations.

6.2	Revisions
HUNTSMAN shall revise and update the RMP submitted as follows:

6.2.1	Submission Dates 
	Within five years of initial submission

	No later than three years after a newly-regulated substance is first listed or used in the plant above the threshold quantity.

	No later than the date on which the substance is first presented in an existing process at or above the threshold quantity. 

	No later than the date on which, a regulated substance is first present in an existing process above a threshold quantity.

	Within 6 months of a change that requires a revised PHA or hazard review. 

	When end point distance has changed be a factor of two or more due to process change, quantities stored change or any other change. 

	Within 1 month of change in reporting personnel. 

	Within 6 months of a change that requires a revised offsite consequence analysis as provided in 40 CFR 68.36

	Within 6 months of a change that alters the Program Level that applies to any covered process. 


6.2.2	 Delisting Notification
If HUNTSMAN is no longer subject to coverage under the RMP, HUNTSMAN will submit a revised registration with the EPA within 6 months indicating that the stationary source is no longer covered.

4.0	Emergency Response
HUNTSMANs emergency response policy involves the preparation and implementation of response plant. The emergency response program is specifically tailored for this site and specifically includes the Epichlorohydrin process. 

4.1.1	Applicability 
HUNTSMAN employees will be the first responders of incidents including accidental release. On determination of the extent of the release, HUNTSMAN will either resolve it internally if it is an incidental incident and involves no public or environmental impact. Anything other than incidental incidents, HUNTSMAN contacts 911 and notifies the local authorities and emergency Haz-Mat team, which is located in York County and will respond with the Fire Department. 

The purpose of the Emergency Response Plan is to protect public health, environment and employees. The following elements are included:

4.1.2	Emergency Response Plan (68.95)
The emergency response plan contains:

4.1.2.1	Procedures for notifying emergency responders about accidental releases.
4.1.2.2	Documentation of proper first-aid and medical treatment necessary to treat victims
4.1.2.3	Procedures for use, inspection, testing and maintenance of emergency response equipment.
4.1.2.4	Training in all relevant procedures for employees involved in the covered processes.

4.1.2.5	Procedures to review and update the response plan to ensure employees are informed of changes. Local emergency officials have been in and are encouraged to attend site visits and review the facility and its emergency response program. 

4.1.2.6	The emergency response plan includes emergency response decision tree and notification plan. Emergency response drills are conducted annually and procedures are updated and retraining occurs as necessary.

3.9.5	Findings and response
HUNTSMAN promptly determines and documents an appropriate response to each finding of the compliance audit and is recorded in its corporate action tracking system

3.9.6	Findings Resolution
HUNTSMAN documents deficiencies that have been corrected in its corporates action tracking system. Completion dates and owners are assigned for each deficiency, and once closed, actions taken are independently verified as meeting the requirement that the  activity is complete. 

3.9.7	Records Retention
HUNTSMAN Maintains all records from the two most recent audits. 

3.10	Incident Investigation
HUNTSMAN investigates all major incidents as soon as possible but notification to Senior Management is no later than 24 hours following the incident.

3.10.2	Team Makeup 
A team investigates each RMP incident and is made up of:
A person knowledgeable with the process
The employee involved in the operation
A contractor representative if a contractor is involved

3.10.3	Report Structure
A written report is prepared for each RMP incident which includes:
	Date of the incident
	Date of investigation
	Description of the incident
	Factors contributing to the incident including the root cause
	Recommendations

3.10.4	Findings resolution
HUNTSMAN addresses and resolves investigation findings and recommendations. All incidents are reviewed at a daily management meetings and monthly management safety meetings.

3.10.5	Finding Review
The findings are reviewed with the personnel, whose job tasks are affected by the findings, including contractors where applicable.

3.10.6	Records Retention
Incident reports including investigation summaries are retained for at least the last 5 years. IF the accident involves personnel injury, medical records are retained as long as the person is employed plus 30 years.?

HAZOP program HUNTSMAN uses evaluates the hazards associated with the following deviations:

 

The team applied these deviations to each node or system to identify the potential hazard and operability scenarios associated with the design. The team then identified the existing protection layers or safeguards that help minimize the severity (consequence) or frequency (likelihood) of the initiating cause propagating to a harmful event.
For each identified scenario, the team employed the Huntsman Risk Matrix to qualitatively assign a severity ranking for the potential consequences associated with personnel safety, environmental effects, or commercial impacts without considering safeguards. The team then similarly assigned a frequency to the harmful event considering the existing safeguards. Where there was a gap identified between the current risk ranking of a scenario and the tolerable frequency as identified on the risk matrix, the team brainstormed risk reduction recommendations.

			Pump Design
Pumps are mag drive pumps for a seal-less design to limit the possibility of pump leaks. 

High Level Alarm
The Epichlorohydrin tank has a high-level alarm set on the weigh tank at 2100 lbs. to prevent overfilling the tank. When activated the alarm will shut off the weigh tank inlet valve and stop the Epichlorohydrin feed pump and display an alarm on the computer.

Vent System
The system vents back to the Epichlorohydrin bulk tank during filling and normal breathing. The closed vent system eliminates the venting of Epichlorohydrin vapors in the area. 

Flow Restriction Orifice
A Flow Restriction Orifice is installed in the weigh tank discharge lines to prevent emptying the tank to the reactors in less than 30 minutes. The orifice is a back-up to the discharge flow control system, and the computer safety interlock programming. Should either of these fail, the orifice will restrict the Epichlorohydrin addition rate to the reactors to prevent the potential for a hot reaction. The flow addition is computer controlled to less than 50 lbs./min faster addition rates can cause the reaction to run hot. 

Reactor Charge Valve Interlock
The reactor Epichlorohydrin charge valves are tied into a hard-wired safety interlock system which will prevent the valves from opening unless specific conditions are satisfied to allow charging Epichlorohydrin to the reactors (liquid level in reactor is above 40 %, temperature is below 65 ?C during the charge). This prevents accidental out of sequence charging of Epichlorohydrin to the reactors and guards against the potential of a hot or runaway reaction.

1.3.1	Worst Case (c) (1)

According to RMP regulations, it should be assumed that, for toxic substances that are normally liquids at ambient temperature and handled as the quantity present in a vessel will be released over 10 minutes, the release rate is assumed to be the total quantity divided by ten minutes. The boiling point temperature for Epichlorohydrin is 241 F, thus Epichlorohydrin is a liquid at ambient temperature. In addition, it is assumed that there is no passive mitigation system in place. Therefore, the release rate was set at 18,900 lbs. /min.

Atmospheric dispersion modeling for the worst-case scenario was performed using the EPA assumptions; results demonstrate a distance of 0.7 miles to the toxic endpoint. The residential population that could be potentially affected by the release is estimated at 2,000 people. 



1.3.2	 Alternative Case (c) (2) 

The alternative release scenario involves a small hole in the Epichlorohydrin Storage Tank.  In this analysis, the rate of Epichlorohydrin released is 30,000 lbs. over 60 minutes (the duration of the release). This equals an average release rate of 500 lbs. per minute.  The toxic endpoint distance determined is still 0.2 miles. The residential population potentially that would be impacted by this release is less than 570 people.
